choices.text: Platelet precursors in the bone marrow are normal or elevated
Leucocyte precursors in the marrow are normal or elevated

questions.text: In myelodysplastic syndrome, the following statement is incorrect:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Always has hypocellular bone marrow

 

Option C:

 

Always has hypocellular bone marrow: This statement is incorrect. MDS is often associated with a hypercellular or normocellular bone marrow and rarely hypocellular bone marrow.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Platelet precursors in the bone marrow are often normal or elevated in myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS). This condition is characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis, and it commonly leads to cytopenias in the peripheral blood.  Thrombocytopenia is a common feature in MDS, and it contributes to the increased risk of bleeding in affected individuals.

 

Option B: Leucocyte precursors in the bone marrow are normal or elevated: This statement is correct

 

Option D: Refractory anemia: This statement is correct. Refractory anemia is a common subtype of MDS, characterized by ineffective erythropoiesis leading to anemia that does not respond well to conventional treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bone marrow in MDS is hypercellular (most commonly) or normocellular (sometimes) or rarely hypocellular

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 620-1)

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of progressive fatigue and a recent diagnosis of alcoholism presents for evaluation. His complete blood count shows a macrocytic anemia and the bone marrow biopsy reveals the presence of ringed sideroblasts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Myelodysplastic syndrome

 

Option B:

 

Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) is associated with ineffective hematopoiesis and the presence of ringed sideroblasts can be a feature when there is a disturbance in iron incorporation into the hemoglobin molecule.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by microcytic, hypochromic red cells without the presence of ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow.

 

Option C. Thalassemia syndromes are hereditary hemoglobinopathies leading to ineffective erythropoiesis and anemia, but they do not typically present with ringed sideroblasts.

 

Option D. Anemia of chronic disease can cause a microcytic anemia, but it is usually normocytic and does not present with ringed sideroblasts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) is associated with ineffective hematopoiesis and the presence of ringed sideroblasts

Ref: Robbins 10th/620
